SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: Which phrase BEST describes the purpose of the text box at the beginning of the passage?

A.Choice: to introduce events described in the passage

Key.Rationale: The text box provides context for how Ando invented ramen noodles.

B.Choice: to explain what ramen noodles are

Key.Rationale: The text box does not give information about what ramen noodles are.

C.Choice: to outline events in the passage in order

Key.Rationale: The text box does not provide the order of any events.

D.Choice: to explain who Momofuku Ando was

Key.Rationale: The text box does not provide details about Ando.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences and/or making generalizations from the text.
Content: Read the excerpt from the passage.

:ibox:“In 1947, the country of Japan was recovering from World War II. Many people were out of work. Food was scarce. One day, a bank manager in Osaka named Momofuku Ando walked past a long line of shivering people. They were waiting at a noodle stand to buy bowls of noodles called ramen.
A big bowl of ramen soup with fish and vegetables was a cheap and tasty meal. Ando never forgot the people standing outside in the cold, just for noodles.”
Which statement BEST expresses Ando's reaction to the people in line?

A.Choice: They reminded him that he was hungry.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support that Ando was hungry when he saw the people in line.

B.Choice: They made him worry that he might lose his job.

Key.Rationale: Even though Ando lost his job years later, there is no evidence that Ando worried about losing his job at the time he saw the people in line.

C.Choice: They reminded him of the effects of war.

Key.Rationale: Even though waiting in line was an effect of war, his reaction was not related to this idea.

D.Choice: They made him think about what people need and want.

Key.Rationale: Seeing people wait in line for ramen made Ando realize the love that people had for ramen and inspired him to “create a new kind of ramen, one that didn't make people wait.”

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:“Ten years later, when he lost his job, that memory [sparked] an idea.”
What does the word “sparked” mean as used in the passage?

Key.Rationale: This option is not the meaning of “sparked” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
The way the word “sparked” is used in the sentence with “idea” allows the reader to discern the meaning as “inspired.”
This option is not the meaning of “sparked” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This option is not the meaning of “sparked” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.

SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which evidence from the passage BEST shows how Ando got the idea for a successful way to dry out the ramen noodles?

A.Choice: “He also wanted people to be able to store his noodles without a refrigerator. So the ramen had to be dried.”

Key.Rationale: This option tells the reader why the ramen had to be dried but not how.

B.Choice: “Then one day, Ando was in the kitchen when his wife was making tempura, battered vegetables cooked in hot oil. Ando watched the tempura bubble as it hit the oil.”

Key.Rationale: Seeing the vegetables cooking in hot oil gave Ando the idea to use oil to dry out the ramen noodles. This made them taste fresh when they were boiled in a little water by consumers.

C.Choice: “Frying noodles had another surprise. It filled the noodles with tiny holes. Those holes made the ramen cook fast with not much water.”

Key.Rationale: This option tells why the ramen can be cooked with little water, but it does not tell how Ando came up with the idea for how to dry the ramen.

D.Choice: “Because it cooked so quickly, with just a little hot water, it was nicknamed 'magic ramen.' Ando's noodles were a hit!”

Key.Rationale: This option tells how the ramen became known as “magic ramen,” but it does not tell how Ando got the idea for how to dry the noodles.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which word is a synonym for the word “estimated” as used in the passage?

Key.Rationale: This option is not a synonym for “estimated” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
This option is not a synonym for “estimated” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.
The word “guessed” is a synonym for “estimated.”
This option is not a synonym for “estimated” and does not make sense in the context of the passage.

SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How does the author support the point that Ando was determined?

A.Choice: by comparing Ando's method of preparing quick ramen with traditional methods

Key.Rationale: Even though the passage mentions traditional methods of making ramen, this comparison does not show that Ando was determined.

B.Choice: by demonstrating that Ando put a lot of effort into the development of quick ramen

Key.Rationale: Ando “experimented with ramen nearly every day for a whole year.”

C.Choice: by explaining how Ando used oil to dry the quick ramen rather than air-drying the noodles

Key.Rationale: Even though Ando did use oil to dry the ramen, this did not show that he was determined since he discovered this solution by chance.

D.Choice: by showing that Ando's quick ramen has been popular around the world for over sixty years

Key.Rationale: The fact that quick ramen is popular does not relate to the point that Ando was determined.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

A.Choice: “He made a list of goals: his noodles had to be tasty, cheap, and quick to cook.”

Key.Rationale: This option shows that Ando was organized and specific in his goals but not that he was determined.

B.Choice: “He tweaked the recipe and dried them in different ways. None had the right texture. But he kept trying.”

Key.Rationale: “He kept trying” shows that Ando did not give up and that he was determined to succeed.

C.Choice: “When the fried ramen noodles were boiled, they tasted like they were fresh.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to Ando being determined.

D.Choice: “These could be made in many different flavors. Ando's first world-wide instant ramen came in one flavor: chicken.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not relate to Ando being determined.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement BEST summarizes the purpose of Ando's ramen product?

A.Choice: It would be a convenient, hot meal that many people could afford.

Key.Rationale: Quick ramen is an inexpensive meal that can be made quickly.

B.Choice: It would be a popular meal because of the variety of flavors.

Key.Rationale: Although the statement is true, this sentence does not summarize the purpose of the product.

C.Choice: It would be a meal that could be eaten in spaceships in the future.

Key.Rationale: Although ramen has been to space, this was not the original purpose of the product.

D.Choice: It would be a meal that no one had ever cooked or eaten before.

Key.Rationale: Quick ramen is based on traditional ramen, a Japanese food that is cooked and eaten by many people.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, steps, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How does the preparation of ramen noodles MOST affect the final product?

A.Choice: To have the best taste, noodles should be cooked using the tempura method.

Key.Rationale: This option is not using tempura but using oil that allows the ramen to have the right texture.

B.Choice: Proper drying methods give noodles the desired texture and preparation time.

Key.Rationale: The use of the oil removes the water, drying it. Then, when the noodles are boiled, they taste fresh, requiring minimal time and water. In addition, the use of special salts with traditional ramen affects their texture.

C.Choice: Customers are more likely to buy noodles prepared with traditional ingredients.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence to support this statement since many people buy the quick ramen noodles.

D.Choice: The noodle seasoning packets are customized to suit regional taste preferences.

Key.Rationale: Even though this statement is true, the question refers to the noodles, not the flavor packets.

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: “Ando bought some second-hand kitchen gear and set up a workshop in his backyard shed.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not directly relate to how the preparation of ramen noodles affects the final product.

B.Choice: “The kansui makes ramen noodles feel springy when you bite into them.”

Key.Rationale: The kansui affects texture.

C.Choice: “That meant they didn't need to be boiled in a big pot with broth—his ramen cooked in two minutes, just by pouring hot water over it.”

Key.Rationale: Ando's method of making quick ramen affected the time and method of preparing.

D.Choice: “They pressed the ramen into a ball shape and made a thick, syrupy broth. This sticks to the noodles even floating around in space.”

Key.Rationale: Pressing the ramen into a ball shape does not relate to the texture or preparation time.

SubTopics: Interpret text features (e.g., headings, graphics, charts) and/or make connections between text and the content of text features.
Content: Why is the chart included at the end of the passage?

A.Choice: to inform the reader about ramen in other countries

Key.Rationale: This option provides information on the different flavors of ramen in various countries.

B.Choice: to explain to the reader why ramen has a museum

Key.Rationale: Even though the ramen museum is mentioned in the chart, this is not the purpose of this text feature since this fact is not expounded on in the chart.

C.Choice: to persuade the reader to try different flavors of ramen

Key.Rationale: Even though readers may be persuaded to try different flavors, this is not the author's purpose.

D.Choice: to show the reader the science behind ramen

Key.Rationale: No scientific information is provided in the chart.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described; describe an author's purpose and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: The passage features a grandmother creating a story for her grandchildren. Write an essay analyzing why the grandmother's story is important to the children. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.

SubTopics: Form and use the perfect verb tenses (e.g., I had walked; I have walked; I will have walked).
Content: Read the sentence.
:ibox:Darcy ___________ her homework by the time dinner is ready.
Which phrase should fill in the blank to correctly complete the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This option is an incorrect construction; “will” indicates future and cannot be used with the past tense “finished.”
The past perfect tense is used to describe a past event that occurred prior to another past event.
The present perfect tense is used to describe an action that started in the past and continues to the present.
The future perfect verb tense should be used to describe the action of Darcy completing her homework before an event that will happen in the future—dinner being ready.

SubTopics: Use a comma to set off the words yes and no (e.g., Yes, thank you), to set off a tag question from the rest of the sentence (e.g., It's true, isn't it?), and to indicate direct address (e.g., Is that you, Steve?).
Content: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

A.Choice: Mr. Hidecki, and the others planned the strategy for the game.

Key.Rationale: A comma is not needed after the name in this instance since it is part of a compound subject.

B.Choice: Ginny it is very difficult to hear you, over the noise outside.

Key.Rationale: A comma is not needed before the prepositional phrase “over the noise outside.”

C.Choice: Barry collected the trash, from the table and threw it away.

Key.Rationale: A comma is not needed before the prepositional phrase “from the table.”

D.Choice: You are probably right about the answer, Beth.

Key.Rationale: The comma placement indicates direct address.

SubTopics: Form and use the perfect verb tenses (e.g., I had walked; I have walked; I will have walked).
Content: Which emphasized verb phrase is used correctly?

A.Choice: Jada [has been starting] her new job at the mall next week.

Key.Rationale: The use of the present perfect progressive tense should be used with a situation that started in the past and is continuing at the present time. Jada starting her new job will occur in the future.

B.Choice: My little brother [will be starting] at a new school last month.

Key.Rationale: The use of the future progressive is incorrect since the event takes place in the past (“last month”).

C.Choice: I [have started] to research the information for my book report yesterday.

Key.Rationale: The use of the present perfect is incorrect since the act of starting to “research the information” has a clear time for when it occurred (“yesterday”). In this case, the simple past tense should be used.

D.Choice: Clark [will have started] decorating for the celebration by the time we get there.

Key.Rationale: The use of the future perfect tense is needed since the action of “decorating” begins in the past and continues into the future.

Content: Read the paragraph.

:ibox:(1) A collection of poems [are] called an anthology. (2) A book editor, who works for a publishing company, [decides] which poems will be in the anthology. (3) Some anthologies [have] a specific theme, such as nature or sports. (4) Others [contain] a variety of poems about many topics.
Which emphasized word should be changed to correct an error in subject-verb agreement?

Key.Rationale: The subject, “collection,” requires a singular verb, which should be “is.”
The subject, “editor,” is singular and requires a singular verb, which is “decides.”
The subject, “anthologies,” is plural and requires a plural verb, which is “have.”
The subject, “Others,” is plural and requires a plural verb, which is “contain.”
